access-control.content: Access Control encompasses the policies, procedures, and technologies used to manage and restrict access to systems, data, and resources based on identity and authorization.

sections.heading: Access Control Models
list: Mandatory Access Control (MAC) - System-enforced labels and classifications
Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) - Access based on job function
Attribute-Based Access Control (ABAC) - Policy-based on attributes
Rule-Based Access Control - Access governed by specific rules

automation.content: Automation in cybersecurity involves using technology to perform repetitive tasks, streamline processes, and improve security operations efficiency.

sections.heading: Tools
list: Ansible, Puppet, Chef for configuration management

aws-security.content: AWS Security encompasses the services, features, and best practices for securing workloads and data in Amazon Web Services cloud environments.

sections.heading: Core Security Services
list: AWS SSO (Identity Center) - Centralized access management
AWS Secrets Manager - Secrets storage and rotation
AWS Certificate Manager - TLS certificate management

sections.heading: Security Monitoring & Detection
list: AWS Security Hub - Security posture management

sections.heading: Network Security
list: AWS Network Firewall - Managed network firewall

azure-security.content: Azure Security encompasses the services, features, and best practices for securing workloads and data in Microsoft Azure cloud environments.

cloud-security.content: Cloud Security encompasses the policies, technologies, and controls deployed to protect data, applications, and infrastructure in cloud computing environments.

cmmc.content: The Cybersecurity Maturity Model Certification (CMMC) is a unified standard for implementing cybersecurity across the Defense Industrial Base (DIB).

sections.heading: CMMC Levels
list: Level 2 - Advanced (110 practices based on NIST 800-171)

sections.heading: Key Requirements
list: Third-party assessment for Level 2 and above

container-security.content: Container Security involves protecting containerized applications and their infrastructure throughout the development lifecycle and runtime.

sections.heading: Security Areas
list: Image Security - Scanning and trusted registries
Runtime Security - Container isolation and monitoring

sections.heading: Tools
list: Aqua, Sysdig, Prisma Cloud for platforms

cryptography.content: Cryptography is the practice of securing information through mathematical techniques to ensure confidentiality, integrity, authentication, and non-repudiation.

sections.heading: Cryptographic Types
list: Symmetric Encryption - Same key for encrypt/decrypt (AES, DES)
Asymmetric Encryption - Public/private key pairs (RSA, ECC)

sections.heading: Applications
list: Data encryption at rest and in transit

devsecops.content: DevSecOps integrates security practices within the DevOps process, embedding security at every phase of the software development lifecycle.

sections.heading: Key Practices
list: Security as Code - Automated security policies
Infrastructure as Code Security - Secure configurations

dfars.content: DFARS (Defense Federal Acquisition Regulation Supplement) contains cybersecurity requirements for Department of Defense contractors handling Controlled Unclassified Information.

documentation.content: Documentation in cybersecurity involves creating, organizing, and maintaining written records of security policies, procedures, architectures, and incidents.

sections.heading: Types of Security Documentation
list: Policies - High-level security requirements and guidelines

sections.heading: Key Documentation Areas
list: Business continuity and disaster recovery plans

ethical-hacking.content: Ethical Hacking involves authorized attempts to bypass system security to identify vulnerabilities that malicious hackers could exploit.

sections.heading: Legal and Ethical Considerations
list: Defined scope and rules of engagement

exploit-development.content: Exploit Development is the process of creating code that takes advantage of software vulnerabilities to gain unauthorized access or control over systems.

exploitation.content: Exploitation is the process of taking advantage of vulnerabilities in software, hardware, or human behavior to gain unauthorized access or cause unintended behavior in systems.

sections.heading: Exploitation Categories
list: Memory Corruption - Buffer overflows, use-after-free, format strings
Web Application - SQL injection, XSS, CSRF, SSRF
Authentication Bypass - Credential attacks, session hijacking
Privilege Escalation - Local and domain privilege elevation

sections.heading: Defensive Applications
sections.content: Understanding exploitation techniques is essential for:

gcp-security.content: GCP Security encompasses the services, features, and best practices for securing workloads and data in Google Cloud Platform environments.

sections.heading: Identity & Access
list: Cloud IAM - Identity and Access Management

governance.content: Security Governance encompasses the framework of policies, processes, and organizational structures that ensure security objectives align with business goals and regulatory requirements.

sections.heading: Key Components
list: Security Strategy - Long-term security direction and objectives
Policies and Standards - Formal security requirements
Organizational Structure - Roles, responsibilities, and accountability
Risk Management - Identifying and managing security risks
Compliance - Meeting regulatory and contractual obligations

hardware.content: Hardware security involves understanding computer components, peripherals, and the security considerations for physical computing devices.

help-desk.content: Help Desk encompasses the front-line IT support services that assist users with technical issues, service requests, and security-related concerns.

sections.heading: Core Functions
list: Incident Management - Responding to and resolving user issues
Service Requests - Handling access requests and provisioning
Problem Management - Identifying root causes of recurring issues
Knowledge Management - Documenting solutions and procedures
User Communication - Keeping users informed of status and resolutions

hipaa.content: HIPAA (Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act) establishes national standards for protecting sensitive patient health information.

sections.heading: Key Rules
list: Security Rule - Safeguards for electronic PHI

sections.heading: Security Rule Safeguards
list: Physical Safeguards - Facility and device security
Technical Safeguards - Access controls and encryption

hitrust.content: HITRUST CSF (Common Security Framework) is a certifiable framework that provides organizations with a comprehensive approach to regulatory compliance and risk management.

identity-access-management.content: Identity and Access Management (IAM) is the framework of policies, processes, and technologies that enables organizations to manage digital identities and control user access to critical information.

sections.heading: Core Components
list: Identity Governance - Lifecycle management and access certification
Access Management - Authentication and authorization services
Privileged Access Management (PAM) - Securing privileged accounts

sections.heading: Key Capabilities
list: Single Sign-On (SSO) - One credential for multiple applications
Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) - Access based on job function

incident-response.content: Incident Response is the organized approach to addressing and managing security breaches or cyberattacks, minimizing damage and reducing recovery time and costs.

sections.heading: Incident Response Phases
list: Preparation - Developing plans, tools, and team capabilities
Identification - Detecting and confirming security incidents
Containment - Limiting the spread and impact of incidents
Eradication - Removing threats from the environment
Recovery - Restoring systems to normal operations
Lessons Learned - Analyzing incidents to improve defenses

sections.heading: Frameworks
list: NIST SP 800-61 (Computer Security Incident Handling Guide)

infrastructure.content: Infrastructure encompasses the physical and virtual components that support an organization's IT operations, including hardware, software, networks, and facilities.

sections.heading: Core Components
list: Storage - SAN, NAS, object storage, backup systems
Networking - Routers, switches, firewalls, load balancers
Data Centers - Physical facilities, power, cooling

iso-27001.content: ISO/IEC 27001 is the international standard for establishing, implementing, maintaining, and continually improving an Information Security Management System (ISMS).

sections.heading: Core Components
list: Context of the Organization - Understanding internal and external factors
Leadership - Top management commitment and policy
Support - Resources, competence, awareness, communication, and documentation
Operation - Implementing and operating the ISMS
Performance Evaluation - Monitoring, measurement, analysis, and evaluation
Improvement - Continual improvement of the ISMS

it-support.content: IT Support involves providing technical assistance to users and maintaining IT systems, ensuring operational efficiency and security across the organization.

linux.content: Linux is an open-source operating system kernel that forms the basis for numerous distributions used in servers, containers, embedded systems, and security tools.

sections.heading: Key Skills
list: Command Line - Shell navigation and scripting
Package Management - apt, yum, dnf, pacman

sections.heading: Common Distributions
list: Red Hat Enterprise Linux / CentOS / Rocky Linux

sections.heading: Security Applications
sections.content: Linux is the platform of choice for:

network-administration.content: Network Administration involves the configuration, management, and maintenance of computer networks to ensure reliable, secure, and efficient communication.

sections.heading: Core Responsibilities
list: Network Design - Planning and implementing network architecture
Configuration - Setting up routers, switches, and firewalls
Monitoring - Tracking network performance and availability
Troubleshooting - Diagnosing and resolving connectivity issues
Documentation - Maintaining network diagrams and configurations

network-security.content: Network Security encompasses the policies, practices, and technologies designed to protect the integrity, confidentiality, and accessibility of computer networks and data.

sections.heading: Key Components
list: Firewalls - Perimeter and internal traffic filtering
VPNs - Secure remote access and site-to-site connectivity
Network Access Control - Endpoint compliance and authentication
Segmentation - Isolating network zones and resources

nist-800-171.content: NIST Special Publication 800-171 provides requirements for protecting the confidentiality of Controlled Unclassified Information (CUI) in non-federal systems and organizations.

sections.heading: Control Families
list: Access Control - Limiting system access to authorized users
Awareness and Training - Security awareness for personnel
Audit and Accountability - Creating and protecting audit records
Configuration Management - Establishing and maintaining baseline configurations
Identification and Authentication - Identifying and authenticating users
Incident Response - Establishing incident handling capabilities
Media Protection - Protecting and sanitizing media
Personnel Security - Screening individuals prior to access
System and Communications Protection - Protecting communications
System and Information Integrity - Identifying and managing flaws

sections.heading: Key Requirements
list: Required for DoD contractors handling CUI

nist-800-53.content: NIST Special Publication 800-53 provides a catalog of security and privacy controls for federal information systems and organizations.

sections.heading: Control Families
list: Assessment, Authorization, and Monitoring (CA) - Security assessments
Physical and Environmental Protection (PE) - Physical security
PII Processing and Transparency (PT) - Privacy controls
System and Services Acquisition (SA) - System development
System and Communications Protection (SC) - Communications security
System and Information Integrity (SI) - Information integrity
Supply Chain Risk Management (SR) - Supply chain security

operating-systems.content: Operating Systems knowledge encompasses understanding the architecture, administration, and security of the software that manages computer hardware and provides services for applications.

sections.heading: Major Platforms
list: Linux - Various distributions for servers and security
Unix - Commercial Unix variants (AIX, Solaris, HP-UX)

penetration-testing.content: Penetration Testing is a systematic process of probing for vulnerabilities in networks, systems, and applications by simulating attacks that a malicious actor might use.

sections.heading: Testing Methodology
list: Planning and Scoping - Defining objectives and boundaries
Scanning and Enumeration - Identifying systems and services
Post-Exploitation - Assessing impact and lateral movement

sections.heading: Testing Types
list: Black Box - No prior knowledge of the target
White Box - Full knowledge including source code
Gray Box - Partial knowledge, simulating insider threat
External - Testing from outside the network
Internal - Testing from within the network

sections.heading: Common Tools
list: Web Testing: Burp Suite, OWASP ZAP
Password Attacks: Hashcat, John the Ripper

privilege-escalation.content: Privilege Escalation refers to techniques used to gain elevated access to resources that are normally protected from an application or user, moving from lower to higher privilege levels.

sections.heading: Types
list: Vertical Escalation - Gaining higher privileges (user to admin)
Horizontal Escalation - Accessing other users' resources at the same level

project-management.content: Project Management in cybersecurity involves planning, organizing, and managing resources to successfully complete security initiatives, implementations, and improvements.

sections.heading: Key Processes
list: Initiation - Defining project scope and objectives
Monitoring and Control - Tracking progress and managing changes
Closing - Completing and documenting the project

red-team.content: Red Teaming is an adversary simulation approach that tests an organization's detection and response capabilities by emulating real-world threat actors' tactics, techniques, and procedures.

sections.heading: Red Team vs Penetration Testing
list: Penetration Testing - Find vulnerabilities within scope
Red Team - Test detection and response with realistic attack scenarios

sections.heading: Collaboration
sections.content: Red teams work with blue teams (defenders) and purple teams (collaborative improvement) to enhance overall security posture.

reverse-engineering.content: Reverse Engineering is the process of analyzing software, hardware, or systems to understand their design, functionality, and behavior without access to source code or documentation.

sections.heading: Applications in Security
list: Malware Analysis - Understanding malicious software behavior
Vulnerability Research - Finding security flaws in software

sections.heading: Tools
list: Disassemblers - IDA Pro, Ghidra, Binary Ninja
Dynamic Analysis - Process Monitor, API Monitor, strace

risk-management.content: Risk Management is the systematic process of identifying, analyzing, evaluating, and treating risks to minimize their impact on an organization's objectives.

sections.heading: Risk Management Process
list: Risk Analysis - Understanding likelihood and impact
Risk Treatment - Selecting and implementing controls
Monitoring and Review - Ongoing risk assessment

sections.heading: Risk Treatment Options
list: Transfer - Share risk through insurance or contracts
Accept - Acknowledge and monitor the risk

security-architecture.content: Security Architecture involves designing, building, and maintaining the security structures and frameworks that protect an organization's information systems and data.

sections.heading: Core Principles
list: Defense in Depth - Multiple layers of security controls
Separation of Duties - Dividing critical functions
Zero Trust - Never trust, always verify
Secure by Design - Building security into systems from the start

security-hardening.content: Security Hardening is the process of securing a system by reducing its attack surface through configuration changes, removing unnecessary services, and applying security controls.

sections.heading: Hardening Areas
list: Operating Systems - Windows, Linux, macOS hardening
Cloud Resources - IaaS, PaaS, SaaS configurations

sections.heading: Common Hardening Steps
list: Encrypt data at rest and in transit

security-management.content: Security Management encompasses the leadership, planning, and oversight of an organization's information security program to protect assets and achieve business objectives.

security-program.content: A Security Program is the comprehensive framework of policies, procedures, technologies, and people that work together to protect an organization's information assets.

sections.heading: Program Elements
list: Risk Management - Identifying and treating risks
Physical Security - Facilities and hardware protection
Incident Response - Detection and response capabilities

shell-scripting.content: Shell Scripting involves writing programs for command-line interpreters to automate tasks, manage systems, and perform security operations.

sections.heading: Common Shells
list: Bash - Default on most Linux distributions
Zsh - Extended Bourne shell with improvements

stakeholder-management.content: Stakeholder Management in cybersecurity involves identifying, engaging, and communicating with individuals and groups who have an interest in or influence over security initiatives.

sections.heading: Key Stakeholders
list: Executive Leadership - Strategic direction and funding
Board of Directors - Governance and oversight

system-administration.content: System Administration encompasses the management, maintenance, and operation of computer systems, servers, and networked environments to ensure reliability, performance, and security.

sections.heading: Key Responsibilities
list: Server Management - Installing, configuring, and maintaining servers
User Administration - Managing user accounts, permissions, and access
System Monitoring - Tracking performance, availability, and health
Backup and Recovery - Implementing data protection and disaster recovery
Patch Management - Applying updates and security patches

tcp-ip.content: TCP/IP is the foundational protocol suite for internet and network communications, enabling data transmission across interconnected networks.

sections.heading: Protocol Layers
list: Application Layer - HTTP, HTTPS, FTP, SMTP, DNS, SSH

sections.heading: Key Concepts
list: IP Addressing - IPv4 and IPv6 addressing schemes
Subnetting - Network segmentation and CIDR notation
Routing - Static and dynamic routing protocols
Port Numbers - Well-known, registered, and dynamic ports
NAT/PAT - Network and port address translation

threat-analysis.content: Threat Analysis is the process of identifying, examining, and understanding potential threats to an organization's assets, systems, and data.

sections.heading: Analysis Components
list: Threat Identification - Discovering potential threat actors and vectors
Threat Assessment - Evaluating likelihood and potential impact
Threat Modeling - Systematic analysis of attack scenarios
Intelligence Gathering - Collecting and correlating threat data

sections.heading: Methodologies
list: STRIDE - Spoofing, Tampering, Repudiation, Information Disclosure, Denial of Service, Elevation of Privilege
PASTA - Process for Attack Simulation and Threat Analysis
OCTAVE - Operationally Critical Threat, Asset, and Vulnerability Evaluation
Kill Chain Analysis - Mapping attack progression stages

threat-vulnerability-management.content: Threat and Vulnerability Management is a continuous, proactive approach to identifying, assessing, prioritizing, and remediating vulnerabilities in an organization's IT infrastructure.

sections.heading: Key Components
list: Vulnerability Scanning - Automated discovery of security weaknesses
Threat Intelligence - Understanding adversary tactics, techniques, and procedures
Risk Assessment - Evaluating vulnerability severity and business impact
Prioritization - Focusing remediation efforts on highest-risk issues
Remediation - Patching, configuration changes, and compensating controls

troubleshooting.content: Troubleshooting is the systematic process of diagnosing, identifying, and resolving problems in computer systems, networks, and applications.

sections.heading: Troubleshooting Methodology
list: Identify the Problem - Gather information and define symptoms
Establish a Theory - Consider probable causes
Test the Theory - Verify or eliminate potential causes
Establish a Plan - Determine corrective action
Implement the Solution - Apply the fix
Document Findings - Record the issue and solution

sections.heading: Common Areas
list: Security - Access problems, malware, authentication failures

sections.heading: Best Practices
list: Change one variable at a time

vulnerability-assessment.content: Vulnerability Assessment is the process of identifying, quantifying, and prioritizing security vulnerabilities in systems, networks, and applications.

sections.heading: Assessment Types
list: Network Vulnerability Scanning - Discovering network-level weaknesses
Host-Based Assessment - Evaluating individual system security
Database Assessment - Checking database security configurations
Cloud Assessment - Evaluating cloud infrastructure security

sections.heading: Assessment Process
list: Asset Discovery - Identifying systems and services
Vulnerability Identification - Scanning for known weaknesses
Remediation Tracking - Following up on fixes

web-application-security.content: Web Application Security focuses on protecting web applications from attacks and vulnerabilities that could compromise data, functionality, or availability.

sections.heading: OWASP Top 10
list: Broken Access Control - Unauthorized access to resources
Cryptographic Failures - Weak or missing encryption
Injection - SQL, NoSQL, OS command injection
Insecure Design - Flawed architecture and design patterns
Security Misconfiguration - Default or weak configurations
Vulnerable Components - Outdated libraries and frameworks
Data Integrity Failures - Untrusted deserialization, CI/CD issues
Logging Failures - Insufficient monitoring and logging

wireless.content: Wireless networking encompasses the technologies, protocols, and security measures for radio-based network communications.

sections.heading: Wireless Attacks
list: Evil twin and rogue access points

zero-trust.content: Zero Trust is a security framework that requires strict identity verification for every person and device attempting to access resources, regardless of their location relative to the network perimeter.

sections.heading: Core Principles
list: Verify Explicitly - Always authenticate and authorize based on all available data points
Least Privilege Access - Limit user access with just-in-time and just-enough-access (JIT/JEA)
Assume Breach - Minimize blast radius and segment access, verify end-to-end encryption
Continuous Validation - Never trust implicitly; continuously validate security posture

sections.heading: Key Components
list: Identity - Strong authentication and identity governance
Devices - Device health and compliance verification
Applications - In-app permissions and shadow IT discovery
Infrastructure - Telemetry, configuration management, and just-in-time access

sections.heading: Implementation Approaches
list: Continuous Adaptive Risk and Trust Assessment (CARTA)
